results.title: Medical electronics
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, Jonathan Donald and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Shows how technology is helping doctors in the three problem areas of time, training and techniques. The use of electronic diagnostic equipment and information retrieval systems, the training methods which allow students to practice on mock-ups of a patient can now overcome many problems. Fibre optics, pressurized operating rooms, and freezing of diseased tissue are among the many treatment techniques described. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Medical Breakthroughs and Prevention
results.brief_description: Worldwide, millions of dollars have been spent on researching ways to combat one of the most deadly and feared diseases known to mankind - cancer. The “Beyond 2000” team takes a penetrating global look at the very latest methods being used to treat cancer and assist existing sufferers. In addition, they examine how preventative medicine is playing an increasingly important role in the war to stop cancer.

results.title: Mediating
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program is about the breakdown of a marriage and the pressures that are brought on the couple to reconcile their differences. Highlights that, in China, society comes before the individual and the family must be maintained, whatever the cost.

results.title: Mediaeval village
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, H.L. Beales, R.S. Lambert and J.B. Holmes
results.brief_description: The social history of Laxton, a village in England in which the medieval open-field system is still used, is traced from monuments and documents. The first map of Laxton, made in 1630, shows the village and the church, and the three open fields divided into strips. Village life as it exists today, with its small individual farmsteads and strip cultivation with crop rotation, is shown to be almost identical with the system displayed on the 1630 map. The second half of the film shows the survival from feudal times of the Manorial Court, or Court Leet. The jury makes the round of the wheat-bearing field, replaces boundary pegs, and imposes fines for encroachment. The Pinder rounds up stray cattle and drives them into the pound. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Mediaeval monastery
results.brief_description: The general work and daily routine of monks in a medieval monastery. Stresses the importance of monasticism in the Middle Ages, distinguishes four main orders. Ground plan of typical monastery; uses of various domestic buildings illustrated by means of superimposed models. Also includes a day in the affairs of Buckfast Abbey, a modern monastery where the ancient rules of the Benedictine Order are observed.

results.title: Mediaeval England
results.creator_credit: Clement W. Bending, Gateway Film Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: Gives a general account of life in medieval England, looking at the life and work of the peasants, the three field system of agriculture, houses of the rich and poor, the church and monastry, the work of the monks and nuns and Holy Day celebrations. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Mediaeval castles
results.brief_description: The Normans built the first castles in England which were simply raised earthworks, with a wooden palisading, surrounded by a ditch. Stone eventually replaced wood. The keep was the central point and its layout and function is explained. Illustrates the methods by which castles were attacked and design improvements of the 12th and 13th Centuries. By the end of the 13th Century castles were built with double walls and nearly impregnable, but the need for them was lessening. The greater part of this program consists of animated drawings and diagrams.

results.title: Media: massaging the mind (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Hobel-Leiterman Productions, Philip S. Hobel, Douglas Leiterman and Patrick Corbett
results.brief_description: Analysis (from a 1970’s point of view) of the future directions of American mass media, Industry people argue for specialised anchors, print journalism, vertical programming and electronic imaging - to name but a few - as the direction for the future. However, such directions are not always considered favourable. Also looks at the role of politics, youth and community in media.

results.title: Media school
results.brief_description: A report on a course in communications with a group of 16 year-old boys from Melbourne High School. The media school is residential and the experiences range through music, mass media and personal relationships. An important featujre is the free open approachto life in general. Made as a segment for the ABC’s “This Day Tonight” program.
